facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 261 of 1958 filed by appellants.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 261 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 6, 1956 of Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 215 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 6, 1956, of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 215 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J. on July 22, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. July 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-This appeal has been filed with the special leave of this Court against a decision of the High Court of Mysore,

facts.text: Appellants applied under Art. 226 for writ of prohibition or other appropriate writ against Income-tax Officer, Bellary, Special Circle, Bangalore.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been filed with the special leave of this Court against a decision of the High Court of Mysore, by which it dismissed in limine an application by the appellants under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ of prohibition or some other appropriate writ against the Income-tax Officer, Bellary, Special Circle, Bangalore.

facts.text: Mysore High Court dismissed the writ petition in limine.

anchor.surface_text: against a decision of the High Court of Mysore, by which it dismissed in limine an application by the appellants under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: For assessment year 1948-49, appellants failed to file return within prescribed time.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case are as follows. For the assessment year 1948-49, the appellants failed to file a return within the prescribed time and the Income-tax Officer,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notice under s. 28(1)(a) to show cause why penalty should be imposed.

anchor.surface_text: acting under s. 28 1  a  of the Indian Incometax Act, issued a numberice to them to show cause why penalty should number be imposed.

facts.text: Appellants filed written reply to the notice.

anchor.surface_text: In answer to this numberice, the appellants filed a written reply and the Income-tax Officer proceeded to levy a penalty of Rs. 16,000,

facts.text: Income-tax Officer levied penalty of Rs. 16,000 without affording hearing as required by third sub-section of s. 28.

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax Officer proceeded to levy a penalty of Rs. 16,000, without affording a hearing to them as required by the third sub-s. of s. 28 of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Appellants appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was taken up in appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, who, pointing out that an opportunity of being heard was number granted to the appellants,

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner set aside the penalty order for lack of opportunity of being heard and directed refund if recovered.

anchor.surface_text: held that the order was defective. He therefore set aside that-order and directed the refund of the penalty if it had been recovered.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued further notice to appellants to appear for opportunity of being heard or proceed on written statement.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of the order, the Income-tax Officer issued a further numberice calling upon the appellants to appear before him, so that they might be given an opportunity of being heard. He also intimated that if numberappearance was made,

facts.text: Before Income-tax Officer decided, appellants filed writ petition under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: then he would proceed to determine the question of penalty, taking into companysideration only the written statement which had been filed earlier. Before, however, the Income-tax Officer companyld decide the case, the appellants filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petition holding contention may be raised before Income-tax authorities.

anchor.surface_text: This petition was dismissed in limine by the High Court holding that the companytention raised by the appellants may perhaps be raised before the Income-tax authorities.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: for the issuance of the writs mentioned above. This petition was dismissed in limine by the High Court holding that the companytention raised by the appellants may perhaps be raised before the Income-tax authorities. The appellants thereupon applied for special leave to this Court and leave having been granted,

facts.text: Requirements of s. 28(1)(a) completely fulfilled as appellants did not file return.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberquestion here that the requirements of s. 28 1  a  of the Income-tax Act were number companypletely fulfilled. If the appellants had number filed their return, as they were required by law to do, the omission would attract cl.  a  of sub-s.  1  of s. 28.

facts.text: Penalty imposed without reasonable opportunity of being heard as required by s.28(3).

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  3  of s. 28, however, requires that the penalty shall number be imposed without affording to the assessee a reasonable opportunity of being heard. This opportunity was denied to the appellants

facts.text: First order of ITO vitiated by illegality during course of proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore the order of the Income-tax Officer was vitiated by an illegality which supervened, ,not at the initial stage of the proceedings, but during the companyrse of it.

facts.text: AAC order directing refund interpreted as correcting error and allowing ITO to continue from stage of illegality.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the learned Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out the ground on which the illegality proceeded and his order directing the refund of the penalty, if recovered, companynot but be interpreted as companyrecting the error and leaving it open to the Income-tax Officer to companytinue his proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred.

facts.text: No express remand necessary for ITO to continue.

anchor.surface_text: No express remand for this purpose, as is companytended, was necessary.

facts.text: Show cause notice did not cease to be operative after AAC order.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the numberice issued to the appellants to show cause why penalty should number be imposed on them did number cease to be operative, because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out an illegality which vitiated the proceeding after it was lawfully initiated.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer can continue the penalty proceedings under section 28 of the Income-tax Act from the stage at which the illegality supervened after the Appellate Assistant Commissioner set aside the original penalty order for violation of section 28(3)?

anchor.surface_text: the requirements of s. 28 1 a of the Income-tax Act were completely fulfilled. If the appellants had not filed their return, as they were required by law to do, the omission would attract cl. a of sub-s. 1 of s. 28. We say nothing as to that. Sub-section 3 of s. 28, however, requires that the penalty shall not be imposed without affording to the assessee a reasonable opportunity of being heard.

issues.text: Whether an express remand by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was necessary for the Income-tax Officer to continue the penalty proceedings after setting aside the defective order?

anchor.surface_text: The order of the learned Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out the ground on which the illegality proceeded and his order directing the refund of the penalty, if recovered, cannot but be interpreted as correcting the error and leaving it open to the Income-tax Officer to continue his proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred. No express remand for this purpose, as is contended, was necessary.

issues.text: Whether the show cause notice issued under section 28(1)(a) ceases to be operative upon the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointing out an illegality that vitiated the proceedings after lawful initiation?

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the notice issued to the appellants to show cause why penalty should be imposed on them did not cease to be operative, because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out an illegality which vitiated the proceeding after it was lawfully initiated.

issues.text: Whether the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner becomes final, preventing the Income-tax Officer from proceeding further, if no appeal is taken by the Commissioner under section 33(2)?

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn to a decision of a learned Single Judge of the Kerala High Court reported in Jos Chacko Poothokaran v. I. T. O., Ernakulam Circle 1 , in which, in similar circumstances, it has been held that since an appeal was not taken by the Commissioner of Income-tax to the Appellate Tribunal under sub-s. 2 of s. 33, the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner became final and the Income-tax Officer could no longer proceed to reassess the penalty. The reason given is, in our opinion, beside the point.

issues.text: Whether penalty proceedings under section 28 can only be taken during the course of assessment proceedings which have concluded?

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out in the course of the statement of the case by the appellants that such proceedings could only be taken during the course of assessment proceedings and those proceedings are concluded.

issues.text: Whether a writ of prohibition under Article 226 should issue to prevent the Income-tax Officer from proceeding with penalty determination after remand-like directions from the Appellate Assistant Commissioner?

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a writ of prohibition or some other appropriate writ against the Income-tax Officer, Bellary, Special Circle, Bangalore. ... the appellants filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution for the issuance of the writs mentioned above.

arguments.court_reasoning: The reason given is, in our opinion, beside the point

arguments.claim: The requirements of s. 28(1)(a) of the Income-tax Act were completely fulfilled

anchor.surface_text: There is no question here that the requirements of s. 28 1  a  of the Income-tax Act were completely fulfilled. If the appellants had not filed their return, as they were required by law to do, the omission would attract cl.  a  of sub-s.  1  of s. 28.

arguments.claim: Sub-section (3) of s. 28 requires that the penalty shall not be imposed without affording to the assessee a reasonable opportunity of being heard; this opportunity was denied and the order vitiated by illegality during the course of proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  3  of s. 28, however, requires that the penalty shall not be imposed without affording to the assessee a reasonable opportunity of being heard. This opportunity was denied to the appellants and therefore the order of the Income-tax Officer was vitiated by an illegality which supervened, not at the initial stage of the proceedings, but during the course of it.

arguments.claim: The order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner directing refund of penalty cannot but be interpreted as correcting the error and leaving it open to the Income-tax Officer to continue proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred

anchor.surface_text: The order of the learned Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out the ground on which the illegality proceeded and his order directing the refund of the penalty, if recovered, cannot but be interpreted as correcting the error and leaving it open to the Income-tax Officer to continue his proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred.

arguments.claim: The notice issued to the appellants to show cause why penalty should not be imposed did not cease to be operative because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out an illegality which vitiated the proceeding after it was lawfully initiated

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the notice issued to the appellants to show cause why penalty should not be imposed on them did not cease to be operative, because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out an illegality which vitiated the proceeding after it was lawfully initiated.

arguments.claim: The reason given in the Kerala High Court decision is beside the point; the Appellate Assistant Commissioner vacated the order and directed refund due to illegality during proceedings, leaving it open to the Income-tax Officer to continue from the point of illegality

anchor.surface_text: The reason given is, in our opinion, beside the point. What the Appellate Assistant Commissioner did was to vacate the order and direct refund of the penalty in view of an illegality which had occurred during the course of the assessment proceedings. On receipt of the record it was open to the Income-tax Officer to take up the matter from the point at which the illegality supervened and to correct his proceedings.

holdings.text: The requirements of s. 28(1)(a) of the Income-tax Act were completely fulfilled since the appellants failed to file their return.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberquestion here that the requirements of s. 28 1  a  of the Income-tax Act were number companypletely fulfilled. If the appellants had number filed their return, as they were required by law to do, the omission would attract cl.  a  of sub-s.  1  of s. 28.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants omitted to file return as required by law, attracting clause (a) of sub-section (1) of s. 28.

holdings.text: The penalty order was vitiated by illegality for denying reasonable opportunity of being heard under s. 28(3), but the illegality supervened during the course of proceedings, not at initiation.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  3  of s. 28, however, requires that the penalty shall number be imposed without affording to the assessee a reasonable opportunity of being heard. This opportunity was denied to the appellants

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-section 3 mandates hearing before imposition; denial vitiates order but allows correction mid-proceedings.

holdings.text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner's order correcting the error and directing refund leaves it open to the Income-tax Officer to continue proceedings from the stage of illegality; no express remand necessary.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the learned Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out the ground on which the illegality proceeded and his order directing the refund of the penalty, if recovered, companynot but be interpreted as companyrecting the error and leaving it open to the Income-tax Officer to companytinue his proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred. No express remand for this purpose, as is companytended, was necessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: AAC order interpreted as remedial, not terminating proceedings; explicit remand not required for continuation.

holdings.text: The show cause notice under s. 28(1)(a) did not cease to be operative after the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out the supervening illegality.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the numberice issued to the appellants to show cause why penalty should number be imposed on them did number cease to be operative, because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out an illegality which vitiated the proceeding after it was lawfully initiated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Initiation lawful; vitiation mid-proceedings does not nullify notice.

holdings.text: Penalty proceedings are not limited to the course of assessment proceedings and do not cease upon their conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the numberice issued to the appellants to show cause why penalty should number be imposed on them did number cease to be operative, because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out an illegality which vitiated the proceeding after it was lawfully initiated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice remains operative post-assessment as long as lawfully initiated.

holdings.text: The reason in Jos Chacko Poothokaran v. I.T.O. is beside the point; AAC vacated order due to mid-proceedings illegality, allowing ITO to continue from that point without further appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The reason given is, in our opinion, beside the point. What the Appellate Assistant Commissioner did was to vacate the order and direct refund of the penalty in view of an illegality which had occurred during the companyrse of the assessment proceedings. On receipt of the record it was open to the Incometax Officer to take up the matter from the point at which the illegality supervened and to companyrect his proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Kerala HC by nature of AAC order as corrective, not final barrier absent appeal.

holdings.text: Writ of prohibition does not lie against Income-tax Officer proceeding with penalty after AAC set aside defective order, as proceedings lawfully initiated and validly continuable.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the learned Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out the ground on which the illegality proceeded and his order directing the refund of the penalty, if recovered, companynot but be interpreted as companyrecting the error and leaving it open to the Income-tax Officer to companytinue his proceedings from the stage at which the illegality occurred. No express remand for this purpose, as is companytended, was necessary. ... In our opinion, the numberice issued to the appellants to show cause why penalty should number be imposed on them did number cease to be operative, because the Appellate Assistant Commissioner pointed out an illegality which vitiated the proceeding after it was lawfully initiated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proceedings valid post-correction; alternative remedy available; no jurisdictional error.
